"The text message to the boys was very clear that everything they do is being tracked and you can see everything. They asked to be moved off your cell
Sent:01/30/2024 at 01:38 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 01/30/2024 at 02:18 PM)
Subject:Re: Friday Practice

plan which I am going to request."
I'm super bummed our kids think there is spying going on and I'm not sure they are getting the most accurate answers to their concerns. So I hope
you can help. To close on the phone and text messaging comments, I want to clarify the history of call/text reporting, the nature of these reports, and
our mutual access to them as account holders. And when I was thinking about it, I realized they have likely never even seen a paper phone bill.
I hope you will tell them that the activity described, which includes calls and texts, has long been a standard practice by phone companies that began
in the 1980s for long-distance calls. Which were expensive. The purpose was to ensure billing accuracy and transparency to customers so they could
manage phone usage. This used to terrify me when I would sneak down River Oaks Parkway every night to secretly call you in Hong Kong.
So as account holders, we both have always had access to this information. It is our family plan after all. I even think we used to get a paper bill
ourselves. But it's not a form of surveillance by me or you. It's a standard feature by ATT for accountability, fraud detection, and accurate record-
keeping. And your status as an account holder inherently includes consent to reporting your data back to you as a part of the service agreement, we
have.
I get without context and having never seen the fat white and blue envelopes with tens of lines of numbers inside, they don't have history. They don't
realize that roommates or families would grab a highlighter and take turns finding their boy or girlfriend's phone number and say which calls were
theirs. Then pull out the calculator to total everyone's share of the bill, just like we did with restaurant tabs when we would split up a big dinner bill.
They should know that our intention was never to monitor or surveil their phone usage. The logs on our bill for phone and text records is just a
routine aspect of our phone service. It has gone on for decades now for good reason. It started with paper fifty years ago and has since largely moved
to an online bill where it's possible to filter, sort, pivot, and categorize history just like you can do with any online date. But it's not spying now or
then.
I hope since you have their ear, and I can't teach them like I used to do, you will explain so they understand. It's just good parenting, and I trust you
will convey the message and ease their unfounded fears. I think we all grew up knowing that every number we dialed would show on the bill so we
sure as hell better not spend all night on the phone with our future wife in Asia. It's just funny how we lost that history and the tribal knowledge
since.
Thanks!

I think we will cancel Rec Hoops practice Friday. Most kids have a dance and Joe is OOF as well. It would be good a good opportunity to let AD
practice AAU this week for a change. That said the quality of play on this particular team (with some exceptions) is pretty freaking good.
I am a little worried about his health. We both agree he was under the weather. I appreciate he wanted to do it. but it's also sketch to try and play at
50%. If he is sick on Sat I might have to tell him he can't play. But he should support the team if possible. Just keep me updated.
I'll be coaching solo again this week on Sat. It was good of Surya to let me know that his dad was complaining about his playing time and they wanted
him in the game more this week... lol Seems like a nice guy but it's a dick move. Take over boss.. show is all yours.

anything on ice for a day (or two).

Otherwise, It's going to take a toll on us.

Maybe a simple Ack or thumbs up on this would make me feel better, but your call.

wrt AD, I’m super concerned all up. I’ll own my contribution to that and want to see how I can start making that right in a healthy way ASAP. That
is a longer discussion but wanted to acknowledge my impact.
wrt SAAS, even if it's a no, we need to agree on a plan that we can share with him ASAP. He needs that settled in his brain no matter what the answer
is. The uncertainty as a child this age is not fair to him and we owe him better.
My thought is that we need to figure out how to make it work. The only question is this year or next.
We don't:
- Want him to go through admissions if we don't have to
Sent:01/31/2024 at 07:41 AM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 01/31/2024 at 08:14 AM)
Subject:Re: Hoops Friday

- Know if even switching this year is an option for us now
- What a reasonable plan would be if he could not move
- Want to start something we are not 100% prepared to act on
- Know if the financial situation is going to be an issue for us
And as an aside, we really need to know what this whole thing means to our future fiscal viability.
I have always hoped we would be civil and even aligned well enough we could think big picture in terms of the actual execution date of the final
paperwork so we could "be divorced" but if it was going to make a ~100k difference (making up a number) that we would be flexible on the date given
all the long term implications.  But even saying that given recent history is kicking a bees nest so let's table that. I assume we won't have that luxury. I
can dream.
So we need to make some assumptions we are not sure will come to pass and come up with a roadmap that assures he can go to SAAS and what it
takes to make that happen. The elephant in the room is when I can find work. That helps a lot with our planning. Even if we have no idea what our
split looks like, we know more money and a dependable revenue stream always helps, no matter what. That is not a debate.
So, there is another bee's nest. As I am wandering around this place, up since five as usual, trying to sort my life from bags and boxes, as you and I
normally are manning our battle stations for the day (again maybe all my fault) I have to be realistic about trying to start an entirely new life (you were
able to continue your sans me), attend therapy, and be ready for the next crazy, while trying to land a job at Amazon or Google. We know the toll that
took on me when you were fully in my corner. So that weighs on my mind as I apply for jobs. And tbh, in my mind there is just no way I can work if
things are like they are now (my fault or not) or even land a job.
So... without a fight, we need to decide if we have enough confidence in our direction and desired decision to make a Go/No Go call on the bullets
above. The reality is we can, we are just at a high risk of getting ourselves into a situation that we cannot sustain. My feeling is we need to have a really
honest discussion about what we see as our next steps. SAAS is a little microcosm of our macro picture that could be a forcing function for us. I went
WAY OFF into the weeds but wanted you to understand my perspective. I want to work. I want to be settled. I want stability. I want to be what I was
to our family for 25 years without the bad parts.
But I am not confident I can do all that in the status quo. But I can assure you my goal is to continue to provide support for my family, monetarily
and emotionally for - you and the kids. That was my lifelong commitment, no matter what.  But it's not going to be solved in OFW. And I am not
pushing you to go off OFW. I am asking for realistic ideas for how we have a peaceful and planful discussion on SAAS right now along with an
acknowledgment of the macro factors that I am trying to consider every day. If this in any way has kicked off a fight, please let me withdraw the
thoughts above and just get back to a SAAS decision this week.
What would you like to do?

we were able to accomplish. We did incredible things that less than a percent of Americans can do. We soared together (obviously at too high a cost)
So while I might be able to do better without you, as a unit of "resource-generating horsepower'', what we did together, as a team, was generational.
I honestly don't believe solo, I can do better without your contributions. You were our backbone, while I was the muscle. Muscles don't work
without strong bones to anchor them. We both need to be realistic about what an amazing and irreplaceable role you played in what we were able to
do together. So, as we discuss "getting a job", it is easy to say. But this muscle no longer has the backbone that made it a success. You were at least 50%
of the equation.
Everything will be different without you.

Sent:01/31/2024 at 05:27 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 01/31/2024 at 05:54 PM)
Subject:Re: Is AD ok?

into normalcy again. Perhaps even what we can look like as a mature family embracing the next chapter and reassuring him it will be even better than
the last. That is why we are doing this after all, and thus far it's a promise not kept.
So this is the 911 call AD deserves right now. He needs to see we are listening to him, and we want to move on to SAAS ASAP and he has a say. Most
importantly, no matter what is going on with us, he will always come first in our life. When he needs us, we will drop anything:  appointments,
schedules, our problems, for him. We put our differences aside and find one voice between us, as it should be when he needs us most.
Proposing you and I do the following:
We try and meet AD where he is, and you even serve as gentle training wheels for us
- I call him tomorrow and say we should all get together to discuss the SAAS option
- I ask if I could come grab him after school Friday to help clean up for a big family meeting
- I pick him up wearing the Homer Simpson shirt he got and a new Nike Tech replacement.
- We go to my place and I show him the progress on all his ideas at the place he picked out
- We decide on a to-do list of home improvements to make it shine before the SAAS summit.
Now it's his day! He is number one and sees it in action. He has a gentle re-entry with Dad as we work on a todo list and we can talk about where he is
at. We get things in order and prepare for Mom!!! Now this is something he never thought that could happen last Monday.
- When you arrive, AD gives you a tour of the place that he picked out and shows off.
- Mom let's him know how pleased and proud of him she is and that he has great ideas.
- We make some popcorn and serve some drinks and he can play host a bit for Mom
- Then we talk about SAAS. largely info we know already, but he has a voice to hear
- We make some foregone conclusions, but he feels like he is driving the decisions
- We can even play a game of ping pong to feel normal again for once since July
Afterward, Dad can serve juicy steaks or Mom and AD head back to Kirkland. Ad knows he is first in our lives and has confidence after seeing us
together that there is no more "lost in our mess" he feels today.
If we can please do this, and put our issues aside, I assure you this could be a game changer on so many levels and possibly accelerate some of the
healing even before we get in front of the shrinks!
It is so important right now that he sees Mom and Dad do what was impossible before. He will go home happy, with hope. It won't solve everything
nor diminish the hard work ahead. But, for a night, he sees anything is possible and perhaps this new life might not be so bad after all.
Remember, I proposed to you to get you back into the Family Photos and we spent the last 29 years together raising three wonderful kids. I hope you
will trust me on this one too!
Please don't say no...

Just had an interesting conversation with her. I called to be sure that she knew phone numbers showed up on our bill but it exploded into how I
ruined her life. I may not agree with some of her characterizations, but that does not matter. It is her perspective. Her perception that it was me alone
trying to figure out what was going on in High School was surprising but understandable.
She told me she saw the cameras in September and thought you had put them up. I wish we had the discussion then. But it was a small point to what
she opened my eyes to. And it is consistent with the talk track you have played to me. That in my alcoholic years, you felt a need to acquiesce to me.
You were just trying to keep the peace and not rock the boat. I needed to hear that.
I understood then as she snuck boys into her room, sent underage porn on her phone, vomited vodka over both sides of the truck (she had been
driving), lost a six-figure full ride to college shoplifting for a boy, and made LBGTQ offensive online posts, what we were doing to get her back on the
rails was mutually agree to. we both were trying to sus things out together.
But her perspective is that it was all me and has always been all me. And now this incident is just a continuation of that behavior. It is important to me
that I know now that I am seen as the villain in this family. That we were not the team I thought we were. And at least in her mind (and maybe yours)
I was doing all these things to be nefarious and ruin her life. I need to think on that.
But most important is the insight into where I think you are coming from. I thought as we were raising our kids we were aligned. But you are washing
your hands clean of that. That this was all me and you had nothing to do with it. It is a history that does not match mine. But I was an active alcoholic
so maybe I was missing things that you were telling me or misinterpreting things.
Either way, it was a deep and insightful lens into the narrative you and the kids have. And at this point in my life, it helps explain a lot. I believe
marriage takes two, but if the perspective is it was all me as some despotic ruler, I want to acknowledge that and do some soul-searching on how this
came to pass. How I thought we were making parenting decisions together but were not.
It has been said that "If you run into an asshole in the morning, you ran into an asshole. If you run into assholes all day, you're the asshole.”
Maybe I'm that asshole...
